Award.AwardTitle: GOALI - Particle Adhesion in Semiconductor Wafer Cleaning

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-0829086
Beaudoin

This proposed research is a combined theoretical and experimental study of the adhesion of micro- and nano-scale particles to nano-structured wafers of interest to the microelectronics community. At present the microelectronics industry has no manufacturable technologies for cleaning future wafers. In particular, the patterns of interest on the wafers are too fragile to be subjected to existing cleaning approaches. The development of new cleaning technologies requires understanding of the contaminant adhesion forces, but the length scales of the patterns on the wafers are rapidly approaching the length scales of the basic forces that control the particle adhesion. This work will measure and model this adhesion.
The Intellectual Merit of the proposed work lies in the new theoretical and experimental methods to be employed to categorize the adhesion of micro- and nano-scale particles to rough nano-patterned or nano-layered surfaces. New theoretical descriptions of the effects of finite, patterned surfaces on the van der Waals and electrostatic adhesion forces between the surfaces will be developed and validated experimentally. Provisions within the research have been made to measure and model capillary forces, should they arise. Colloidal probe microscopy will be performed to allow adhesion forces between the substrates and the particles to be measured directly. The use of focused ion beam/scanning electron microscopy (FIB/SEM) or scanning transmission electron microscopy/energy-filtered transmission electron microscopy (STEM/EFTEM) to create 3D maps of particle geometry and morphology with nano-scale precision will allow creation of detailed models of the particle surfaces. These will be used in force models that predict the observed adhesion. Such models will be the first of their kind.
The Broader Impacts of this work are articulated in several fashions. First, the technical results of the work are of profound importance to the microelectonics industry, as the industry currently possesses no manufacturable approaches for cleaning future wafers and photomasks. Particle adhesion is also critically important to the pharmaceutical industry where particle flows and particle mixing are essential processes, and in homeland security matters, where sampling and sensing of nano- and micro-particles of explosives, biological agents, or radioactive agents is necessary. The proposed work will also be part of an outreach effort to a local elementary school that will involve over 120 second graders and 6 teachers each year. The students and teachers will travel to Purdue in small groups and will use the AFM to make topographical maps of leaves, grass, CDs, DVDs, fingernails, hair and skin. They will take the images they collect and use them to reinforce the content they are learning in the classroom using lessons jointly developed by Beaudoin and the teaching staff. The industry partner in this work, FSI International (FSI), will provide wafers, particle deposition capability, wafer cleaning capability, and metrology for evaluating wafer cleaning effectiveness. Beaudoin will perform particle adhesion and modeling studies on the wafers provided by FSI, and will feed the results of these studies back to FSI. FSI, in turn, will use these results to optimize the operation of its cryogenic aerosol-based wafer cleaner, and will document the accuracy of Beaudoin's adhesion models. FSI also will host Beaudoin's student for one month each summer to perform experiments in an industrial setting at FSI.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of the proposed work was the development and validation of a new scheme for describing adhesion of nano- and micro- scale particles to nano- and micro-patterned surfaces.  This goal was achieved, as experimentally-validated models for the adhesion of micro- to nano-scale particles to patterned surfaces were developed and disseminated via technical conferences and journal articles in the refereed literature.  The journal articles in which the work was described were. 

 

1)            Jaiswal, R. and Beaudoin, S., In Press, Langmuir (2012).

2)            Balachandran, D., et al., In Press, Powder Technology (2012).

3)            Kilroy, C., et al., IEEE Transactions on Semiconductor Manufacturing, 25 (1), 37 - 44 (2012).

4)            Jaiswal, R. and Beaudoin, S., Journal of Adhesion Science and Technology, 25, 781-797 (2011).

5)            Jaiswal, R., et al., Langmuir, 25 (18), 10612–10623 (2009).

 

The conferences at which this work was presented were: 

 

1)            Balachandran, D. and Beaudoin, S., Annual Meeting of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, Minneapolis, MN, November (2011).

2)            Beaudoin, S., Trace Explosives Detection Workshop, Portland, OR, April (2011).

3)            Beaudoin, S., BEST (Building Excellence in Science and Technology) Seminar Series, Andrews University, February (2011).

4)            Smith, K. M., et al., Annual Meeting of American Institute of Chemical Engineers, Minneapolis, MN (2011). 

5)            Smith, K. M., et al., Annual Meeting of The Electrochemical Society, Boston, MA (2011). 

6)            Smith, K., et al., 2010 Annual Meeting of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, Salt Lake City, UT (November, 2010).

7)            Zarate, N., et al., Annual Meeting of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, Salt Lake City, November (2010).

8)            Balachandran, D., et al., Annual Meeting of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, Salt Lake City, November (2010).

9)            Chaffee-Cipich, M., and Beaudoin, S. P., Annual Meeting of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, Salt Lake City, November (2010).

10)        Smith, K., and Beaudoin, S., 7th Annual SEMATECH Mask Cleaning Workshop, Monterey, CA (September, 2010).

11)        Cipich, M., et al., Trace Explosives Detection Workshop, Baltimore, MD, May (2010).

12)        Balachandran, D., et al., Annual Meeting of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, Nashville, November (2009).

13)        Jaiswal, R., et al., Annual General Meeting of the International Fine Particle Research Institute (IFPRI), Ann Arbor, MI, June (2009).

14)        Kilroy, C., et al.,  Gordon Res...

This goal was achieved, as experimentally-validated models for the adhesion of micro- to nano-scale particles to patterned surfaces were developed and disseminated via technical conferences and journal articles in the refereed literature. The journal articles in which the work was described were. 1) Jaiswal, R. and Beaudoin, S., In Press, Langmuir (2012). 2) Balachandran, D., et al., In Press, Powder Technology (2012). 3) Kilroy, C., et al., IEEE Transactions on Semiconductor Manufacturing, 25 (1), 37 - 44 (2012). 4) Jaiswal, R. and Beaudoin, S., Journal of Adhesion Science and Technology, 25, 781-797 (2011). 5) Jaiswal, R., et al., Langmuir, 25 (18), 10612–10623 (2009). P., Annual Meeting of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, Salt Lake City, November (2010). 10) Smith, K., and Beaudoin, S., 7th Annual SEMATECH Mask Cleaning Workshop, Monterey, CA (September, 2010). 11) Cipich, M., et al., Trace Explosives Detection Workshop, Baltimore, MD, May (2010). 12) Balachandran, D., et al., Annual Meeting of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, Nashville, November (2009). 13) Jaiswal, R., et al., Annual General Meeting of the International Fine Particle Research Institute (IFPRI), Ann Arbor, MI, June (2009). 14) Kilroy, C., et al., Gordon Research Conference – Detecting Illicit Substance: Explosives and Drugs, Les Diablerets, SWITZERLAND, June (2009). 15) Beaudoin, S., et al., Trace Detection Workshop, Combating Terrorism Technical Support Office, Technical Support Working Group (TSWG), Arlington, VA, February (2009). 16) Beaudoin, S., et al., Trace Sampling Workshop, Department of Homeland Security, Science and Technology Directorate, Transportation Security Laboratory, Atlantic City, NJ, February (2009). A representative result is shown here. Figure 1 shows the 3 key calculations that must be performed in order to calculate adhesion forces between rough, nonuniform, nanopatterned surfaces. In this figure, co- and off-axial opposing cylinders are shown, and the vector components of their interaction force (van der Waals force) are indicated. Describing these 3 adhesion systems allows the adhesion between rough, nano-patterned surfaces to be described. Figure 2 demonstrates the ability developed in this work to calculate the adhesion for the systems shown in Figure 1. Specifically, in Figure 2 we show predicted adhesion forces between pairs of opposing cylinders, as calculated using a full numerical solution (labeled FNS) of the controlling force equations and using the simulat...
